ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: An overview of current research in computational neuroscience / cogsci, opportunity to participate in weekly class discussion with people from a variety of backgrounds. You learn that the computational bases for things we often take for granted (visual perception, intuitive understanding of physics, tool use) are highly non-trivial, but not intractable from an experimental perspective.

I learnt how to tackle burning questions in psychological research using a computational approach. I learnt about cutting edge computational models used to solve problems in vision science and how they work, and learnt how to discuss limitations of these models and ways they can be improved to better reflect real visual experience.

This course was very effective at introducing students to the discipline of thinking about, developing and evaluating computational models of cognition. It covered the history as well as the state of the art. It also gave students the research independence in the field, by having students compose weekly reading reflections, participate in dynamic discussions, and complete a term project.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Course material was very interesting, weekly assignments were unique (students were asked to find a related paper to the readings for the week instead of just writing a response), and Professor Yildirim, despite being extremely knowledgeable and accomplished, encouraged all students to speak up and share their perspectives, which would make for very involved and interesting class discussions.

Discussion-based class, so would not recommend taking if you are unprepared to share / sometime lead in class discussions.

Professor Ilker was a very patient, passionate and engaging lecturer who was great at sparking interesting discussions about cutting edge research in computational vision science. The weekly readings were well structured to allow us to expand our knowledge and build a foundational understanding of concepts in vision science such as intuitive physics so that we can discuss it in class.

The course was overall very strong. The seminar style as well as the final project greatly facilitated student learning as well as student independence in the field.

Since the seminar is small, and since both undergraduates and graduate students (some of whom are in the professor's lab) at times it felt that there was a very large imbalance in the ability of students to contribute and be a part of the discussion. Professor Yildirim was aware of this issue and worked to mitigate it, but it nonetheless persisted at times.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Highly recommend. It is discussion-based, so would recommending making sure you are prepared to participate in weekly discussions before taking.
I would highly recommend this course to another student that wants to learn about how computational techniques can deepen our understanding of psychological concepts especially in vision science.
